Legal_Issue: Whether the citizenship judge erred in applying only the physical presence test for residency requirements
Governing_Law: Citizenship Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. C-29, sect. 5(1)(c)
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant provided insufficient proof of physical presence (161 days)
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate compliance with residency requirement
Legal_Rule: Applicant must be physically present in Canada for at least 1095 days in the last four years
Procedural_Issue: Judge did not consider qualitative or contextual approaches such as in Takla
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error in legal interpretation by citizenship judge
Key_Evidence_Considered: Number of days of physical presence (161 days)
Legal_Framework: Citizenship Act and applicable jurisprudence including Pourghasemi
Applicant_Challenge: Chaudhry challenged the narrow application of the physical presence test
Legal_Rule_Source: Citizenship Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. C-29, sect. 5(1)(c)
Outcome: Application denied; applicant may reapply if requirements are met
Resolution_Mechanism: Judicial review under section 14(5) of the Citizenship Act
Legal_Provision: Section 5(1)(c) and section 14(5) of the Citizenship Act
Legal_Provision_Cited: Citizenship Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. C-29, sect. 5(1)(c); section 14(5)
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Failure to meet physical presence requirement for residency
Pending_Relief_or_Application: Reapplication for citizenship if eligibility is met
Governing_Rule: Physical presence test as established in Pourghasemi
